title.narrative: National peace and stability is enhanced through a harmonised and coordinated peace mechanism
Number of occurrences of consensus building by different political and scoial actors to address differences without resorting to violent conflict

comment.narrative:
A major recurrent source of conflict and violence in Ghana is the cycle of democratic elections and usually there arises conflict and violence in particular between supporters of the two major political parties. there are more than 24 party-backed armed vigilante groups now operating in Ghana, making prevention of political violence a major challenge. The National Peace Council's(NPC) core mandate is to facilitate and develop non-violent strategies to prevent, manage, and resolve conflict and to build sustainable peace in Ghana.
Peace status in 2019: 1. No public education and awareness on the Vigilante Act, 2019 (Act 999); 2. Lack of public knowledge on the Roadmap and the Code of Conduct for the eradication of vigilantism in Ghana 3. 107 hotspots in all the 16 regions of Ghana

title.narrative: Sensitisation and advocacy campaign on the Roadmap & Code of Conduct and the Vigilantism and Related Offences Act (Act 999) undertaken
Number of political party members and other relevant stakeholder representatives reached

comment.narrative:
The run-up to every general election in Ghana since 1992 has been marked by mistrust, tensions and anxiety. The isolated records of violent acts, mistrust and tensions characterized with Ghana’s election cycle have been attributed in part to the ‘winner-takes-all’ politics, which virtuous makes the loser losing all to the winner in elections. This is because the state, in otherwise the Executive, is the main provider of employment and security and thus party supporters believe that access to power and state resources will be available to them only when their party wins the elections. Party suppoThe Vigilantism and Related Offences Act (999) of 2019, the Roadmap on the Eradication of Vigilantism and the Code of Conduct against Vigilantism have been prepared and need to be publicised and for relevant actotrs to be trained ahead of the general elections in Ghana.
The baseline sitiation is that the Act and related Roadmap and Code of Conduct have zero reach, and have not been publicised.

title.narrative: Youth groups in 8 ECOWAS member states engaged in coordinated peacebuilding initiatives
# of youth groups engaged in conflict prevention initiatives

comment.narrative:
There is a worsening regional security situation which could likely spill over more and more into Ghana. Although there is no immediate threat of terror or extremist attacks in Ghana, there are growing concerns about the spread of extremist groups across West Africa, including Ghana. The steep rise in extremist attacks in neighbouring Burkina Faso has substantially increased the influx of migrants, mainly women and children, settling in northern Ghana, where tensions between local residents and migrants over limited resources such as lands, water and food are already a destabilising factor.
The baseline situation is a weak coordination of youth conflict prevention actions

title.narrative: Local and national response structures developed
- Number of local and national response structures - Response structures feeding to National & ECOWAS Early Warning and Response Systems

comment.narrative:
WANEP is the leading regional CSO in conflict prevention and peacebuilding and has established national networks in all ECOWAS countries, with more than 500 member organizations across West Africa. It is implementing a regional early warning and response system with ECOWAS and has MOUs with both the African Union Commission and ECOWAS to provide support to the Peace and Security Departments and in support of ECPF and APSA.
In 2019, the situation was: • No established local early warning and response structure • WANEP National Early Warning System (NEWS) present in ECOWAS member states • 1 established national peace architecture (NPC) in West Africa
